title: 105_hr4733
content:
The Trade Adjustment Assistance Reform Act of 1998 is also known as the Consolidated Trade Adjustment Assistance Act. It authorizes appropriations for trade adjustment assistance programs. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Reform Act of 1998 authorizes appropriations for trade adjustment assistance programs and repeals the NAFTA Transitional Adjustment Assistance Program. No assistance, vouchers, allowances, or payments may be provided after September 30, 2003 under chapter 2, and no technical assistance may be provided under chapter 3. SEC. 3. Filing of petitions and provision of rapid response assistance; expedited review by Secretary of Labor. Section 221(a) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow petitions for certification of eligibility for adjustment assistance to be filed by workers, unions, employers, one-stop career centers, or state employment agencies. Upon receipt of a petition, the Governor must transmit it promptly. Governor must transmit petitions to the Secretary of Labor promptly, provide assistance in reviewing the petition, and ensure rapid response assistance for affected workers. The Secretary will publish notice in the Federal Register upon receiving the petition for investigation. In 19 U.S.C. 2273(a), the time frame for action is reduced from 60 days to 40 days. SEC. 4. ADDITION OF SHIFT IN PRODUCTION AS BASIS FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR TRADE ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE. Section 222(a) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to certify a group of workers for adjustment assistance if workers have been separated or are threatened to be separated, and if there is a decrease in sales or production while imports of competitive articles have increased. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to provide adjustment assistance to workers if imports have increased, leading to separation or threat of separation, and decline in sales or production. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON CERTAIN CERTIFICATIONS.

Amends Section 223 of the Trade Act of 1974 to require the Secretary to collect and maintain information on countries where firms have shifted production resulting in certifications, and countries from which imports have resulted in certifications.

SEC. 6. ENROLLMENT IN TRAINING REQUIREMENT. Section 231(a)(5)(A) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include enrollment requirements for workers facing total separation from adversely affected employment. The enrollment must occur within specific timeframes after separation or certification issuance by the Secretary. The Secretary may extend the enrollment period for workers facing total separation from adversely affected employment under specified circumstances. SEC. 7. WAIVERS OF TRAINING REQUIREMENTS. Section 231(c) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow the Secretary to waive training requirements for a worker if it is not feasible or appropriate, based on factors such as potential recall by the firm or possessing marketable skills. The Trade Act of 1974 allows the Secretary to waive training requirements for a worker if certain conditions are met, such as being close to qualifying for old-age insurance benefits, unable to participate in training due to health reasons, and having the first available enrollment date for approved training within 45 days. The Secretary can waive training requirements under the Trade Act of 1974 if funds are insufficient, training duration exceeds entitlements, and other financial support is not guaranteed. The duration of the waiver is specified by the Secretary and periodically reviewed. The Secretary can waive training requirements under the Trade Act of 1974 if funds are insufficient or training duration exceeds entitlements. The waiver is periodically reviewed, and if the basis is no longer applicable, it will be revoked. The Secretary may authorize States to carry out activities described in the waiver agreement, excluding certain determinations. An annual report is submitted to Congress identifying the number of workers receiving waivers and their average duration. The Trade Act of 1974 allows waivers for training requirements if funds are insufficient or training duration exceeds entitlements. The waivers are periodically reviewed and may be revoked if no longer applicable. States can be authorized to carry out activities under the waiver agreement, with an annual report to Congress on the number of workers receiving waivers and their average duration. Section 231(a)(5)(C) of the Act is amended by removing "certified". SEC. 8 amends the Trade Act of 1974 to provide trade readjustment allowances for 30 days during breaks in training. SEC. 9 increases the annual total amount of payments for training to $150,000,000. SEC. 10 eliminates the quarterly report requirement. SEC. 11 coordinates with One-Stop Career Centers, the Job Training Partnership Act, and the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. Section 235 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include services provided through one-stop career centers. Section 239(e) is amended to coordinate with the Job Training Partnership Act and the Workforce Investment Act of 1998, including common reporting systems and elements. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include services provided through one-stop career centers, coordinating with other acts and common reporting systems. Elements related to participant data and performance outcomes are emphasized. SEC. 238A. SUPPORTIVE SERVICES are added to the Trade Act of 1974, focusing on services offered through one-stop career centers and coordination with other acts. Adversely affected workers covered by a certification under the Trade Act of 1974 can apply for supportive services such as transportation and child care through the Secretary. Approval is based on the necessity for training participation and consistency with the Job Training Partnership Act. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Reform Act of 1998 and the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provide provisions for dislocated worker employment and training activities. The table of contents of the Act is amended accordingly. SEC. 13. ADDITIONAL CONFORMING AMENDMENTS to the Trade Act of 1974, amending sections 225(b) and 240(a) by removing references to specific subchapters. SEC. 14. AVAILABILITY OF CONTINGENCY FUNDS. SEC. 14. AVAILABILITY OF CONTINGENCY FUNDS. Amends Section 245 of the Trade Act of 1974 to authorize contingency funds if program funds are exhausted in a fiscal year. SEC. 15. REAUTHORIZATION OF ADJUSTMENT ASSISTANCE FOR FIRMS. Amends Section 256(b) to extend adjustment assistance for firms through 2003. The Presidential Commission on Workers and Economic Change in the New Economy is established. The Presidential Commission on Workers and Economic Change in the New Economy is established to conduct a thorough study on economic dislocation and worker adjustment, focusing on the impact of trade, technology, and education programs in assisting workers. The Presidential Commission on Workers and Economic Change in the New Economy will study worker adjustment to economic change, including program design, workplace education, public-private partnerships, and income support. The Commission will consist of 15 members appointed by the President, including Members of Congress, workforce development professionals, and educators. The Commission, consisting of workforce development professionals, educators, State agency heads, business leaders, and labor organization representatives, will have powers and authority similar to the Twenty-First Century Workforce Commission. Within 18 months of its first meeting, the Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress detailing its findings and conclusions from the study conducted. The Commission will provide a report on best practices for worker education and training, along with recommendations for legislative actions. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 1999. SEC. 17. Effective Date; Transition Provision. This Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment. The Secretary of Labor can establish rules for a smooth transition from old laws.
